pull_request.title: MassMatrix3::PrincipalMoments, diagonalizing the moment of inertia matrix

update.description:
As a follow-up to pull request #77, this adds the `PrincipalMoments` function to the `MassMatrix3` class, which computes the eigenvalues of the moment of inertia matrix using the algorithm described in the following paper:

* [A Method for Fast Diagonalization of a 2x2 or 3x3 Real Symmetric Matrix](http://arxiv.org/abs/1306.6291v4) by Maarten Kronenburg

The next pull request will add a function that computes the rotational offset of the principal axes (based on the rotation of the eigenvectors of the moment of inertia matrix). See [branch mass_matrix](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/branches/compare/mass_matrix%0Dign-math2) for a preview.

Note that line 361 has no test coverage because that line should never be reached, but I left the check to be safe and prevent a divide by zero.

I tried to comment the code to match the equations in the paper. It's maybe a little dry, but I'm happy to explain the math/code in person if anyone has any questions. I can also provide an octave script or ipython notebook to verify the eigenvalues of the matrices used in the test.

pullrequest.title: MassMatrix3::PrincipalMoments, diagonalizing the moment of inertia matrix

content.raw: I've [already written the code for the eigenvectors](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/branches/compare/mass_matrix%0Dign-math2#Linclude/ignition/math/MassMatrix3.hhT379) based on this same paper; I'm just saving it for the next pull request. Since a real symmetric has orthogonal eigenvectors that can be represented with a rotation matrix, the "eigenvector method" computes a quaternion that can be easily converted to a rotation matrix.
content.html: I've already written the code for the eigenvectors based on this same paper; I'm just saving it for the next pull request. Since a real symmetric has orthogonal eigenvectors that can be represented with a rotation matrix, the "eigenvector method" computes a quaternion that can be easily converted to a rotation matrix.

pullrequest.title: MassMatrix3::PrincipalMoments, diagonalizing the moment of inertia matrix

content.html:
This will require heap allocation which can be slow and isn't needed for a small fixed size sort. You could do it like this instead:

// On return a<=b.
inline void sort2(int& a, int& b) {
    if (a>b) std::swap(a,b);
}
// On return a<=b<=c.
inline void sort3(int& a, int& b, int& c) {
    sort2(a,b); // a<=b
    sort2(b,c); // a<=c, b<=c
    sort2(a,b); // a<=b<=c
}

content.html: This is very nice. In general it would be very useful to be able to get the eigenvectors as well (handy for drawing the inertia ellipsoid, e.g.). If Kronenburg's method can provide them this might be a good time to code that while you are the master of the method.

pull_request.title: MassMatrix3::PrincipalMoments, diagonalizing the moment of inertia matrix

pullrequest.title: MassMatrix3::PrincipalMoments, diagonalizing the moment of inertia matrix

content.raw:
Oh, that's interesting Steve! I tried it in Simbody and it didn't complain. Changing one of the off-diagonals to `-1.0000001` made it fail though, with this error message:
```
Test failed due to exception: SimTK Exception thrown at MassProperties.h:555:
  Error detected by Simbody method Inertia::Inertia(moments,products): 
  The magnitude of a product of inertia was too large to be physical.
```
But from the eigenvalues it looks like this is *way* violated so I should have caught it. Diagonalizing would be a much better way for check for badness -- I didn't realize the current check was inadequate and will be complaining to the guy who gave me that checking code! Here's the check in Simbody:
```c++
    // Thanks to Paul Mitiguy for this condition on products of inertia.
    SimTK_ERRCHK(   Ixx+Slop>=std::abs(2*Iyz) 
                 && Iyy+Slop>=std::abs(2*Ixz)
                 && Izz+Slop>=std::abs(2*Ixy),
        methodName,
        "The magnitude of a product of inertia was too large to be physical.");
```
"Slop" is around 1e-8.
content.html:
Oh, that's interesting Steve! I tried it in Simbody and it didn't complain. Changing one of the off-diagonals to -1.0000001 made it fail though, with this error message:

Test failed due to exception: SimTK Exception thrown at MassProperties.h:555:
  Error detected by Simbody method Inertia::Inertia(moments,products): 
  The magnitude of a product of inertia was too large to be physical.

But from the eigenvalues it looks like this is way violated so I should have caught it. Diagonalizing would be a much better way for check for badness -- I didn't realize the current check was inadequate and will be complaining to the guy who gave me that checking code! Here's the check in Simbody:

    // Thanks to Paul Mitiguy for this condition on products of inertia.
    SimTK_ERRCHK(   Ixx+Slop>=std::abs(2*Iyz) 
                 && Iyy+Slop>=std::abs(2*Ixz)
                 && Izz+Slop>=std::abs(2*Ixy),
        methodName,
        "The magnitude of a product of inertia was too large to be physical.");

"Slop" is around 1e-8.

pull_request.title: MassMatrix3::PrincipalMoments, diagonalizing the moment of inertia matrix

pullrequest.title: MassMatrix3::PrincipalMoments, diagonalizing the moment of inertia matrix

content.raw:
I didn't implement the 2x2 solver, but it's much easier :)

Also, I ran across the useful test case of a tridiagonal matrix from finite element methods:

~~~
x = [2 -1  0
    -1  2 -1
     0 -1  2]
~~~

Incidentally, this is one of Gilbert Strang's favorite matrices, as it is symmetric and positive definite. In this form it isn't obvious that it violates the triangle inequality, but diagonalizing shows that it does (see [the test](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/79/massmatrix3-principalmoments-diagonalizing/diff#Lsrc/MassMatrix3_TEST.ccT287) for its eigenvalues). I wonder if simbody would catch this or not.
content.html:
I didn't implement the 2x2 solver, but it's much easier :)

Also, I ran across the useful test case of a tridiagonal matrix from finite element methods:

x = [2 -1  0
    -1  2 -1
     0 -1  2]

Incidentally, this is one of Gilbert Strang's favorite matrices, as it is symmetric and positive definite. In this form it isn't obvious that it violates the triangle inequality, but diagonalizing shows that it does (see the test for its eigenvalues). I wonder if simbody would catch this or not.

pull_request.title: MassMatrix3::PrincipalMoments, diagonalizing the moment of inertia matrix

pullrequest.title: MassMatrix3::PrincipalMoments, diagonalizing the moment of inertia matrix

content.raw: Cool! I would definitely like a specialized 2x2 and 3x3 eigensolver for symmetric matrices. David Eberly has one also [here](http://www.geometrictools.com/Documentation/RobustEigenSymmetric3x3.pdf) but I don't know if either of these is better. Currently I can only do this in Simbody by using the Lapack Eigensolver which is definitely overkill for a 3x3.
content.html: Cool! I would definitely like a specialized 2x2 and 3x3 eigensolver for symmetric matrices. David Eberly has one also here but I don't know if either of these is better. Currently I can only do this in Simbody by using the Lapack Eigensolver which is definitely overkill for a 3x3.

content.raw:
[should be fixed now](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/33/)

two tests were using `M_SQRT2` without the following:

~~~
#ifndef _USE_MATH_DEFINES
# define _USE_MATH_DEFINES
#endif
#include <cmath>
~~~
content.html:
should be fixed now

two tests were using M_SQRT2 without the following:

#ifndef _USE_MATH_DEFINES
# define _USE_MATH_DEFINES
#endif
#include <cmath>
